## Creating the Foundation

<a href="#">
  <img 
    src="no-paint.jpg" 
    alt="Metal and Concrete Mixing" 
    style="float: left; margin-right: 20px; width: 350px; transition: transform 0.3s ease;"
    onmouseover="this.style.transform='translateY(-10px)';"
    onmouseout="this.style.transform='translateY(0)';"
  />
</a>

<p>
We started by recovering recycled metal from abandoned mattresses. The springs were heated to straighten them and then cut using a plier. This metal was mixed with concrete to create our homemade weight plates.
</p>

<div style="clear: both; margin-top: 60px;"></div>

## Painting the Weights

<a href="#">
  <img 
    src="painting.jpg" 
    alt="Painting Process" 
    style="float: right; margin-left: 20px; width: 350px; transition: transform 0.3s ease;"
    onmouseover="this.style.transform='translateY(-10px)';"
    onmouseout="this.style.transform='translateY(0)';"
  />
</a>

<p>
Once the concrete dried, the plates were coated in matte black paint. At this stage, we finalized the 5kg weight plate design. However, we could only produce six at a time.
</p>

<div style="clear: both; margin-top: 60px;"></div>

## Reflection

<p style="max-width: 800px; margin: 0 auto; font-size: 1.1rem; line-height: 1.7;">
At the core of the EVCIM project is a belief that <strong>fitness should be accessible to everyone</strong>. Gym equipment, especially weights, can be expensive — but through recycling, creativity, and sheer trial-and-error, we’ve managed to design <strong>affordable, functional weights</strong> from materials that would’ve ended up in landfills.
</p>

<p style="max-width: 800px; margin: 0 auto; font-size: 1.1rem; line-height: 1.7;">
We’re not just making plates — we’re building a <strong>movement</strong> where passion meets sustainability. And we’re not stopping until <strong>everyone</strong> can train, lift, and grow without breaking the bank.
</p>
